QualityAssuranceProcedure: This content is in draft and still under development. Do not use this as final content

Classes.Name: Actuator
Classes.Definition: An actuator is a mechanical device for moving or controlling a mechanism or system. An actuator takes energy, usually created by air, electricity, or liquid, and converts it into one or the other type of motion.

Classes.Name: Air handling unit
Classes.Definition: An air handling unit comprises several components, serving in particular to filter, heat, cool, humidify or dehumidify air and then distribute it in a building. An AHU can be a single integrated whole or composed of modules aggregated as needed.

Classes.Name: Air-to-air exchanger
Classes.Definition: An air-to-air exchanger is a device serving to transfer heat between 2 crossed air flows. The classic example is dual-flow mechanical ventilation with heat recovery, via such an exchanger. Here the heat from the air extracted from the building is transferred to the fresh air entering from outside for injection into the building during the heating period.

Classes.Name: Audiovisual device
Classes.Definition: An audio-visual appliance is a device that displays, captures, transmits, or receives audio or video. Audio-visual appliances may be fixed in place or may be able to be moved from one space to another. They may require an electrical supply that may be supplied either by an electrical circuit or provided from a local battery source. Audio-visual appliances may be connected to data circuits including specialist circuits for audio-visual purposes only.

Classes.Name: Beam
Classes.Definition: A beam is a generally horizontal (sometimes oblique) linear construction element serving to pick up linear or concentrated loads – mainly vertical but sometimes horizontal – by bending above an opening and to transmit them to the structural elements below (columns, walls. ..). Beams also cover lattice beams, composed of several inter-articulated linear structural elements forming a triangulation (frame member)

Classes.Name: Breeching inlet
Classes.Definition: A coupler is a connection system intended to supply the fire extinguisher network. These connectors are generally found outside the building for the connection of a water supply (via fire truck for example).

Classes.Name: Cable tray
Classes.Definition: A cable tray is a device permitting the passage of electrical cables. These can be hung on the wall/ceiling or placed on the floor. We can distinguish perforated sheet metal (open or closed) models, wire or ladder models and closed models. This data sheet covers only straight sections of cable trays, see below for other cable tray components.

Classes.Name: Cable tray connection
Classes.Definition: A cable tray is a device permitting the passage of electrical cables. These can be hung on the wall/ceiling or placed on the floor. We can distinguish perforated sheet metal (open or closed) models, wire or ladder models and closed models. This data sheet covers only the connectors between straight sections such as corners, T-connectors, 4-branch connectors and reductions, see below for the straight elements of the cable trays.

Classes.Name: Caisson foundation
Classes.Definition: A caisson is a deep foundation that transmits the loads of a structure to the deeper layers of the ground. The load is transmitted by lateral friction and/or at the point. This type of structure is used when the loads to be transmitted to the ground are too great to work with direct foundations and/or when the bearing capacity of the upper layers of the ground is too low.

Classes.Name: Ceiling finishing
Classes.Definition: This sheet contains all the finishing layers for ceilings. These are always non-load bearing layers.

Classes.Name: Chiller
Classes.Definition: A cooling generator is a device used to extract heat from a liquid via a refrigeration cycle (vapour compression or absorption) to cool a fluid, usually water or a mixture of water and glycol. The cooled fluid then serves to cool and dehumidify the air in a building by blowing (via ventilation system, cold beam, etc.) or by radiation (cold ceiling/floor).

Classes.Name: Chimney
Classes.Definition: A chimney is a flue for the evacuation of combustion gases from a combustion heat generation system (wood, oil, gas, etc.) generally arranged vertically. A chimney can be fully prefabricated (single or double-walled flue with integrated insulation) or built on site (exterior masonry + insulation + steel flue, terracotta refractory lining… on a case-by-case basis). The same chimney can contain one or more flues. A chimney can also comprise concentric ducts known as “suction ducts”, with one of the ducts providing fresh air for combustion and the other serving to evacuate the combustion gases.

Classes.Name: Column
Classes.Definition: A column or a pillar (embedded in a wall) is a generally vertical (sometimes oblique) construction element serving to take concentrated loads - mainly compression but also horizontal - and to transmit them to the structural elements below.

Classes.Name: Curtain wall
Classes.Definition: A curtain wall is a vertical (or almost vertical), partially or completely glazed wall, which closes the spaces of a building vertically, generally running outside and not between the floor slabs. This wall is composed of several elements:

Classes.Name: Damper and register
Classes.Definition: A flap is an equipment item that allows the airflow through a duct to be closed off as needed (0 or 100%): fire-blocking flap at compartmentalisation level, … A damper is an equipment item that allows the airflow to be adjusted gradually, manually or with a motor. When the flow adjustment is integrated into the final element of the circuit (grille), this element is considered to be a vent with integrated flap/damper.

Classes.Name: Data device
Classes.Definition: A data device is a device that serves to exchange computer data. It generally requires a power supply and can be fixed or movable. Devices intended primarily for Audio and/or Video are not included here.

Classes.Name: Deep foundation
Classes.Definition: A pile is a deep foundation that transmits the loads of a structure to the deeper layers of the ground. The load is transmitted by lateral friction and/or at the tip. This type of structure is used when the loads to be transmitted to the ground are too great to work with direct foundations and/or when the bearing capacity of the upper layers of the ground is too low.

Classes.Name: Door
Classes.Definition: A door is a construction element that serves mainly to provide controlled access to persons and goods. It mainly takes the form of vertical openings but also includes horizontal openings (hatches). A door generally consists of a frame (fixed part) and one or more panels (moving parts), plus accessories such as hinges and pivoting, sliding or folding hardware. It can also incorporate solar or blackout protection.

Classes.Name: Electric appliance
Classes.Definition: An electrical appliance covers devices, both fixed and movable, intended to run on electricity, excluding communication, multimedia, permanent and/or fixed heating and cooling appliances.

Classes.Name: Electrical generator
Classes.Definition: An electricity generator is a device that converts kinetic energy into electricity, consisting of a fuel-powered motor or turbine that drives an electric generator. In certain cases it can also produce heat (co-generation).

Classes.Name: Electrical outlet
Classes.Definition: A switch is an accessory belonging to an electrical distribution network that makes it possible to control and modulate the intensity of the electrical current downstream. A switch makes it possible to control a power current, a communication or audio-visual signal, or any other type of flow.

Classes.Name: Electrical panel
Classes.Definition: An electrical panel is a box through which electrical power passes and is distributed to the various circuits. It can contain safety and protection devices (circuit breaker, differential), energy metering, circuit management and control (relays, dimmers, home automation control module, etc.).

Classes.Name: Electrical protection equipment
Classes.Definition: Electrical protective equipment serves to automatically cut an electrical circuit when a limit condition is reached: Excessive current due to overload or short-circuit (circuit breaker, fuse…), loss of current (differential), overvoltage (Varistor)… Some accessories are also provided for manual actions with a view to isolating certain circuits, for example in order to work on this circuit.

Classes.Name: Electrical switch
Classes.Definition: A switch is an accessory belonging to an electrical distribution network that makes it possible to control and modulate the intensity of the electrical current downstream. A switch makes it possible to control a power current, a communication or audio-visual signal, or any other type of flow.

Classes.Name: Electrical transformer
Classes.Definition: A transformer is an electrical component which uses induction to modify the voltage and the intensity of the current between 2 distinct electrical circuits. This data sheet covers only power transformers. Additional components built into the transformer can change the frequency and type (AC-DC) of the current. Some transformers serve to protect against electrocution.

Classes.Name: Electricity storage
Classes.Definition: An electricity storage device serves to store energy, in different forms: chemical, capacitive, inductive. It stores incoming electrical energy and releases it as and when needed. These devices also serve to "clean" an electric current by removing certain elements of the electric current generated by the electric power elements: capacitive phase shift, inductive phase shift, harmonics.

Classes.Name: False ceiling
Classes.Definition: A suspended or false ceiling serves to conceal the technical and/or structural elements which pass above the ceiling. With a dismantlable ceiling, the ceiling tiles can be easily opened for adapting the technical equipment to the evolving needs of the premises.

Classes.Name: Fan
Classes.Definition: A fan is a mechanical element intended to set a gas, generally air, in motion, for blowing it into and/or extracting it from a building through the ventilation system. It can be centralised or decentralised. A fan can be a sub-component of a more diversified device: A.H.U. (air handling unit), double flow ventilation unit with heat recovery…

Classes.Name: Filter
Classes.Definition: A ventilation filter serves to remove or at least reduce particulate matter or gases from the air.

Classes.Name: Fire hose reel
Classes.Definition: A fire hose reel is a flexible hose that is connected to a hydrant in order to extinguish a fire. It is often supported by a reel and the ensemble is known as a hydrant or reel depending on the region

Classes.Name: Fire hydrant
Classes.Definition: A fire hydrant serves to connect a fire hose to a water supply for extinguishing out a fire. Fire hydrants can be found inside buildings, generally in fire boxes (permanent supply = wet column, or solely as needed = dry column). Outdoors, there are fire hydrants connected to the city's water supply network.

Classes.Name: Fire protection cabinet
Classes.Definition: A fire cabinet is intended to centralise and store fire protection equipment in a way that is easily identifiable by its colour (red or white with red logo in Luxembourg and neighbouring countries). This cabinet can contain fire extinguishers, a fire hose or hose reel, a coupler for a distribution column and other accessories.

Classes.Name: Floor finishing
Classes.Definition: This sheet contains all the finishing layers for interior and exterior floors. These are always non-load bearing layers.

Classes.Name: Foundation beam
Classes.Definition: A foundation beam is used to distribute the loads of a structure over direct or deep foundations such as insulated footings, piles or foundation caissons.

Classes.Name: Foundation footing
Classes.Definition: A strip (or continuous) footing is an infrastructure work, generally in reinforced concrete, which takes up the loads from a structural element of a construction and transmits and distributes these loads directly onto the ground (trench bottom or base level). In this case we speak here of a direct foundation. For example, we find examples of strip footing under a wall.

Classes.Name: Furniture
Classes.Definition: A furniture includes all the components of a piece of furniture or equipment fixed or not to the building, such as chair, desk, table ... both for indoor and outdoor use. Note that technical equipment (electrical, telecommunications, sanitary ...) do not belong to this category of object.

Classes.Name: Heat diffusion - radiator
Classes.Definition: Radiators use a combination of radiation and/or natural convection with a heat source such as electricity, steam or hot water to heat a space or a limited area. Radiators and heated towel rails are examples of heat diffusers with centralised generation. Electric radiators and towel-rails are examples of decentralised surface diffusion heating devices.

Classes.Name: Heat production - steam
Classes.Definition: A heating steam generation system is a closed tank in which water or another fluid is heated to a temperature above 100°C using an energy source such as natural gas, fuel oil or electricity. The fluid in the tank is then discharged from the device for use in various processes or heating applications.

Classes.Name: Heat production - water
Classes.Definition: A water or fluid heating system consists of a closed, pressure-resistant tank in which water or another fluid is heated using an energy source such as natural gas, fuel oil or electricity. The fluid in the tank is then discharged from the device for use in various processes or heating applications.

Classes.Name: Heat/cold diffusion - surface
Classes.Definition: Surface heat or cooling diffusers work by radiation via an exchanger (pipes, possibly with conductive diffusers) using a heat source such as electricity, steam or hot water to heat a space or a limited area. Wet underfloor heating (water pipes in screed) and dry underfloor heating (pipes clipped into profile + metal mesh diffuser under the floor covering), underfloor heating with direct expansion of the refrigerant gas, and active false ceilings are all examples of surface heat diffusers with centralised generation. Electrically heated floors and ceilings are examples of local surface diffusion heating devices.

Classes.Name: Lift
Classes.Definition: A lift is an item of transport equipment that serves to transport persons and/or goods between two different levels of a building in a closed cabin or car.

Classes.Name: Lightfixture
Classes.Definition: A light fixture is intended to provide artificial lighting, it can include the light fixture itself but also the lamp(s), transformer, dimmers and other accessories.

Classes.Name: Linear structural member
Classes.Definition: A frame element is a horizontal, vertical or oblique linear construction element (posts and columns excluded), generally in wood/steel/concrete, serving to transfer loads by bending and/or compression and/or traction. The structural elements can be components of the roof structure (purlin, rafters, component of a truss), the floor structure but also components of lattice beams (lower and upper cross-members, vertical and oblique uprights), bracings for buildings, wall structure elements (timber frame, curtain wall, etc.), etc.

Classes.Name: Management panel
Classes.Definition: A controller is a device that monitors inputs and controls outputs in a building automation system.

Classes.Name: Pump
Classes.Definition: A pump is a device that transmits mechanical force to fluids or sludge in order to move them through a pipeline. A pump can be part of various networks, such as the water supply network (hot water loop, booster), the heating/cooling network (circulator for heat/cooling distribution, oil pump, pump), the sewer system (lift pump), and the fire extinguishing network.

Classes.Name: Ramp
Classes.Definition: A ramp is an inclined surface construction element that connects spaces at different levels on foot or with a wheeled vehicle (wheelchair, car, etc.). It does not normally have a step. A ramp may consist of one or more inclined planes separated by horizontal landings. There is a difference between a ramp laid on the ground and a ramp that is supported:

Classes.Name: Roof
Classes.Definition: A roof is a surface element, flat or otherwise, horizontal or inclined, which closes off the upper part of the spaces of a building against the outside. It can also be an outdoor space covered by a roof. We distinguish between two main construction systems:

Classes.Name: Roof finishing
Classes.Definition: This sheet contains all the finishing layers for roofs. These are always non-load bearing layers.

Classes.Name: Safety lighting
Classes.Definition: An emergency light fixture serves to provide artificial lighting with the objective of guiding occupants in an emergency situation. It can include the light fixture itself but also the lamp(s), transformer, dimmers and other accessories.

Classes.Name: Sanitary equipment
Classes.Definition: A sanitary equipment item is a device connected to the water supply network and generally also to the water drainage network. This data sheet covers a long list of devices, such as bidet, toilet bowl, toilet flush, shower tray, bath, sink, water fountain, urinal, hand basin etc.

Classes.Name: Sanitary/heating pipe
Classes.Definition: A pipe is an element of generally circular section along which flows a fluid, liquid, gas or solid in powder form, under pressure or not, in certain cases by gravity. A pipe can be flexible or rigid and generally belongs to a network. Uses include water supply (city water, rainwater, grey water), energy distribution (water/steam for heating or cooling), fire extinguishing distribution, sanitation (roof water downpipe, water waste, buried sewer, drainage…), fuel distribution network (oil, gas…), centralised vacuum cleaning system, fountains and plant watering…

Classes.Name: Sanitary/heating pipe fitting
Classes.Definition: A pipe fitting includes, among others, elbows, section change adapters, T- and other-shaped fittings, and plugs. A fitting is part of a network composed of pipes (segments and fittings) of generally circular section intended for the flow of a fluid, liquid, gas or solid in powder form, under pressure or not, in certain cases by gravity. A pipe can be flexible or rigid. Types of networks include water supply (city water, rainwater, grey water), energy distribution (water/steam for heating or cooling), fire extinguishing substance distribution, sanitation (roof water downpipe, water waste, buried sewer, drainage…), fuel distribution network (oil, gas…), centralised vacuum cleaning system, fountains and plant watering…

Classes.Name: Slab
Classes.Definition: A slab or floor is a normally horizontal surface element that partitions the spaces of a building (interior space/exterior space) horizontally. This element is composed of load-bearing structural layers which transfer the loads to vertical load-bearing elements (walls, columns), in certain cases via beams.

Classes.Name: Slab-on-grade
Classes.Definition: A ground slab is a horizontal constructive element which is placed on the ground in sub-layers (insulation, waterproofing, draining stones, etc.). A distinction is made between load-bearing and non-load-bearing ground slabs

Classes.Name: Solar panel
Classes.Definition: A solar collector converts solar energy into another energy form: electricity from photovoltaic panels and heat from solar thermal panels. There are also hybrid panels combining the two technologies in a single panel.

Classes.Name: Sprinkler
Classes.Definition: A sprinkler is a fixed automatic water extinguishing installation that is self-activated in the event of excessive heat in a protected room or site during a fire. This system is networked and consists of extinguisher heads screwed onto pipes, connected to a control station which regulates the water supply.

Classes.Name: Stair
Classes.Definition: A stair is a construction element set at an incline that connects spaces located at different levels, for foot access only. A staircase can consist of one or more flights separated by horizontal landings. A distinction is made between a staircase resting on the ground and a self-bearing staircase:

Classes.Name: Tank
Classes.Definition: A tank is a container generally used to store a fluid or gas for later use, under pressure or not (oil tank, rainwater tank, fire extinguishing water tank, gas tank, septic tank, grey water for treatment storage tank …). A tank can also service to regulate pressure in a network (expansion tank), to remove over-pressures (pressure breaker bottle), to store heat/cold (buffer tank, hot water tank, ice tank …).

Classes.Name: Technical floor
Classes.Definition: A technical floor or raised floor permits quick and easy access to the technical area under this floor, for adapting the technical installations to the changing needs of the premises.

Classes.Name: Ventilation air terminal
Classes.Definition: A vent is the origin or end point between an air distribution system and a space (room). A vent can have different shapes (linear, circular, rectangular), different directions of diffusion and additional functions (flow rate adjustment, etc.).

Classes.Name: Ventilation duct
Classes.Definition: A ventilation duct is a duct serving to distribute air in a building, eventually after treatment (filtering, heating, cooling, humidification, etc.).

Classes.Name: Ventilation duct connection
Classes.Definition: A ventilation duct is a duct serving to distribute air in a building, eventually after treatment (filtering, heating, cooling, humidification, etc.). A duct fitting includes elbows, section change adapters, T-fittings and other shaped fittings, plugs, etc.

Classes.Name: Ventilation silencer
Classes.Definition: A ventilation silencer serves to reduce the transmission, through the interior of the duct, of the noise created by the ventilation system components (fan, air movement, etc.) or coming from a room.

Classes.Name: Wall
Classes.Definition: A wall is a flat, vertical (or nearly vertical) partition, either opaque or partially or completely glazed, that divides the spaces of a building (inside spaces/outside spaces/site) vertically. This element may or may not be load-bearing. If it is load-bearing, it consists of a load-bearing structural part which can be in a monolithic material (concrete, masonry, etc.) or of the frame type (wood, metal, etc.). The structural role may differ on a case-by-case basis, including:

Classes.Name: Wall finishing
Classes.Definition: This sheet contains all the finishing layers for the interior and exterior walls. These are always non-load bearing layers.

Classes.Name: Water collector
Classes.Definition: A gutter is a piping system serving to collect rainwater at the base of the slopes of a roof.

Classes.Name: Window
Classes.Definition: A window is a construction element that serves mainly to bring in natural light and fresh air. It takes the form of vertical openings but also horizontal openings such as roof windows or dome skylights. A window consists of a frame (fixed part) and one or more panels (moving parts), plus accessories such as hinges and pivoting, sliding or folding hardware. It can also incorporate solar protection or occlusion.

Classes.Name: Zone
Classes.Definition: A zone is a group of spaces and/or zones that generally share common properties in terms of use and/or performance requirements. Zones can be inside or outside. The grouping can be, for example, by wing, by department, by housing unit (1 apartment = 1 zone), by temperature setpoint zone, etc.

Properties.Name: Acoustic resistance
Properties.Definition: Indicates the resistance of sound transmission through this object.

Properties.Name: Activation temperature
Properties.Definition: Defines the temperature at which the object is designed to activate.

Properties.Name: Air temperature (cooling)
Properties.Definition: Indicates the supply air temperature in cooling mode.

Properties.Name: Air temperature (heating)
Properties.Definition: Indicates the supply air temperature in heating mode.

Properties.Name: Airflow type
Properties.Definition: Describes the type of airflow that the equipment produces.

Properties.Name: Backup system
Properties.Definition: Indicates the type of backup supply system.

Properties.Name: Bulletproof
Properties.Definition: Indicates the resistance of the door against bullet passage (according to STS 53.1)

Properties.Name: Cabin depth
Properties.Definition: Gives the clear depth of the object (elevator). It indicates the distance from the inner surface of the elevator door to the opposite surface of the elevator car.

Properties.Name: Cabin height
Properties.Definition: Gives the clear height of the object (elevator).

Properties.Name: Cabin width
Properties.Definition: Gives the clear width of the object (elevator). It indicates the distance from the inner surfaces of the elevator car left and right from the elevator door.

Properties.Name: Cabinet with lock
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the file cabinet is lockable (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Capacity
Properties.Definition: Gives the product of the ideal capacity and the overall volumetric efficiency of the compressor.

Properties.Name: Capacity flush (volume)
Properties.Definition: Gives the volumetric capacity of the flush.

Properties.Name: Capacity in persons
Properties.Definition: Indicates the capacity of the transportation element measured in numbers of person.

Properties.Name: Capacity in weight
Properties.Definition: Indicates the capacity of the transport element measured by weight.

Properties.Name: Ceiling finishing
Properties.Definition: Indicates the ceiling finish material if not modelled separately.

Properties.Name: Condition - Condition assessed
Properties.Definition: Gives the overall condition of a product based on an assessment of the contributions to the overall condition made by the various criteria considered. The meanings given to the values of assessed condition should be agreed and documented by local agreements. For instance, is overall condition measured on a scale of 1 - 10 or by assigning names such as Good, OK, Poor.

Properties.Name: Condition - Date of evaluation
Properties.Definition: Indicates the date on which the overall condition was assessed.

Properties.Name: Connection size
Properties.Definition: Indicates the size of the pump connections.

Properties.Name: Construction method
Properties.Definition: Defines whether the concrete element is constructed on site (IN-SITU) or prefabricated (PRECAST).

Properties.Name: Convector type
Properties.Definition: Indicates the type of convector, whether forced air (mechanically driven) or natural (gravity).

Properties.Name: Covered area
Properties.Definition: Defined the area the sprinkler is designed to protect.

Properties.Name: Current
Properties.Definition: Indicates the current that a device is designed to handle.

Properties.Name: Description
Properties.Definition: Describes the use of the furniture.

Properties.Name: Diameter
Properties.Definition: Indicates the bore of the hose.

Properties.Name: Direction of the emergency picto
Properties.Definition: Indicates the direction of escape pictogram.

Properties.Name: Documentation
Properties.Definition: Indicates the link to the documentation related to the element.

Properties.Name: Effective load
Properties.Definition: Indicates the boiler real load.

Properties.Name: Effective volume
Properties.Definition: Indicates the effective (real) volume of the tank.

Properties.Name: Electrical power
Properties.Definition: Defines the power of the luminaire.

Properties.Name: End date of guarantee
Properties.Definition: Indicates the date on which the warranty expires.

Properties.Name: Energy consumption
Properties.Definition: Defines the energy consumption of the boiler.

Properties.Name: Energy efficiency
Properties.Definition: Defines the operational efficiency of the cooling unit: cooling output divided by the total energy input (electrical and fuel).

Properties.Name: Fire rating
Properties.Definition: Also called "fire resistance". Describes the ability of a building component to maintain, for a specified period of time, load-bearing capacity (R), integrity (E), insulation (I) and/or any other required function. In general, the fire resistance classes are expressed as follows: REI t, R t, EI t, E t, S t, where t is the period expressed in minutes.

Properties.Name: Fire risk factor
Properties.Definition: Defines,according to local building regulations, the fire risk of the space at several levels of fire hazard.

Properties.Name: Flammability rating
Properties.Definition:
Also called "reaction to fire". Determines the way a material reacts when it comes into contact with a contact with a contact with heat source. The reaction-to-fire requirements for construction products products are described according to the classification classification (main classes and sub-classes smoke production and flaming droplet formation. formation) from NBN EN 13501-1/ILNAS-EN 13501-1. Remarks :
- the requirements in this respect relate to the final application value application value (thus taking into account the presence of the presence of any underlying (flammable) materials).

Properties.Name: Floor finishing
Properties.Definition: Indicates the floor finish material in case it is not modelled separately.

Properties.Name: Flow rate range
Properties.Definition: Indicates the allowable pumping rate range in relation to the resistance.

Properties.Name: Flush type
Properties.Definition: Indicates which type of flush the toilet is equipped with.

Properties.Name: Glass layers
Properties.Definition: Indicates the number of glass layers within the frame. E.g. "2" for double glazing.

Properties.Name: Glazing area fraction
Properties.Definition: Indicates the fraction of the glazing area relative to the total area of the frame.

Properties.Name: Has access control
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the door is equipped with door access control (badge or code, etc.) (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Has caps
Properties.Definition: Indicates if the inlet connection has protective caps.

Properties.Name: Has diffuser
Properties.Definition: Indication of whether the sprinkler has a deflector (baffle) fitted to diffuse the discharge on activation (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Has external sill
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the window opening has an external sill (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Has internal sill
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the window opening has an internal sill (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Has motorized opening
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the door is equipped with automatic closing (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Has sprinklers
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the space is sprinkler protected (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Has tray
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the shower has a tray (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Humidity summer (cooling)
Properties.Definition: Defines the required relative humidity of the space or area in summer. Specified by the user or designer and used as a set point for cooling.

Properties.Name: Humidity winter (heating)
Properties.Definition: Defines the required relative humidity of the space or area in winter. Specified by the user or designer and used as a set point for heating.

Properties.Name: IFC Object Type
Properties.Definition: Defines the object type if the type is USERDEFINED. This gives an additional indication of the type of object.

Properties.Name: IFC Type
Properties.Definition: Defines the specific information about IFC type which is a subtype of the IFC class.

Properties.Name: Inlet diameter
Properties.Definition: Indicates the inlet diameter of the breeching inlet.

Properties.Name: Is automatic
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether flushing is activated automatically after each use or periodically (TRUE) or whether manual flushing is required (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Is automatic shading device
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the blackout device is automatic (TRUE) or not (FALSE)

Properties.Name: Is emergency exit
Properties.Definition: Indication whether this object is designed to serve as an exit in the case of fire (TRUE) or not (FALSE). Here it defines an exit door in accordance to the national building code.

Properties.Name: Is emergency exit area
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether this space is an emergency exit (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Is external
Properties.Definition: Indication whether the element is designed for use in the exterior (TRUE) or not (FALSE). If TRUE it is an external element that supports the weather conditions (cold, humidity, rain,...)

Properties.Name: Is external (Archicad)
Properties.Definition: Indication whether the element is designed for use in the exterior (TRUE) or not (FALSE). If TRUE it is an external element and faces the outside of the building.

Properties.Name: Is firemen access
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the elevator is designed to serve as a fire fighting lift the case of fire (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Is handicap accessible
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the element is designed to be accessible to the disabled (TRUE) or not (FALSE). This information is often used to declare the need for disabled access or for special design constraints.

Properties.Name: Is load-bearing
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the object is intended to carry loads (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Is load-bearing (Archicad)
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the element is intended to carry loads (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Is load-bearing (Revit)
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the element is intended to carry loads (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Is mobile shading device
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the blackout device is movable (TRUE) or not (FALSE)

Properties.Name: Is outer shell
Properties.Definition: Determines whether the element is part of the external envelope of the building (TRUE) or not (FALSE). In other words whether it is an element between the heated volume and the external environment.

Properties.Name: Is physically attached
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the furniture type is 'built in' physically attached to a building or facility (TRUE) or movable (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Is public accessible
Properties.Definition: Indication whether this space (in case of e.g., a toilet) is designed to serve as a publicly accessible space, e.g., for a public toilet (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Length
Properties.Definition: Indicates the length of the hose fitted to the hose reel when fully extended.

Properties.Name: Light switch
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the switch is equipped with an indicator light (TRUE) or not (FALSE).

Properties.Name: Luminous flux
Properties.Definition: Indicates the amount of light energy emitted by the source.

Properties.Name: Maintenance factor
Properties.Definition: Defines the calculation made for the depreciation of lamps and reflective equipment from their original value due to dirt, smoke or age.

Properties.Name: Material
Properties.Definition: The basic entity for naming and defining materials; this includes identification by name and classification (by reference to an external classification), as well as the association of material properties (isotropic or anisotropic) defined by (subtypes of) IfcMaterialProperties. An instance of IfcMaterial can be associated with an element or an element type using the IfcRelAssociatesMaterial relationship.

Properties.Name: Maximum cooling temperature
Properties.Definition: Defines the maximal temperature of the space or zone allowed for the hot (summer) period, that is required from user/designer view point and provided as requirement for cooling.

Properties.Name: Maximum heating temperature
Properties.Definition: Defines the maximum temperature of the space or area allowed in winter. Specified by the user or designer and used as a set point for heating.

Properties.Name: Maximum output power
Properties.Definition: Indicates the maximum output power rating of the engine.

Properties.Name: Maximum pressure
Properties.Definition: Indicates the maximum pressure that the hydrant is manufactured to withstand.

Properties.Name: Measured air volume flow
Properties.Definition: Indicates the actual airflow measured on site.

Properties.Name: Mechanical ventilation required
Properties.Definition: Indicates the requirement of a particular mechanical air ventilation rate, given in air changes per hour.

Properties.Name: Minimum cooling temperature
Properties.Definition: Defines the minimum temperature of the space or area allowed in summer. Specified by the user or designer and used as a set point for cooling.

Properties.Name: Minimum headroom
Properties.Definition: Headroom required for the activity assigned to this space.

Properties.Name: Minimum heating temperature
Properties.Definition: Defines the minimum temperature of the space or area allowad in winter. Specified by the user or designer and used as a set point for heating.

Properties.Name: Mounting type
Properties.Definition: Identifies reel type.

Properties.Name: Net programmed area
Properties.Definition: Indicates the total planned net area for the space. Used for programming the space.

Properties.Name: Nominal air flow
Properties.Definition: Indicates the actual airflow rate as designed.

Properties.Name: Nominal efficiency (steam)
Properties.Definition: Defines the total efficiency of the steam heat production equipment as defined by the manufacturer.

Properties.Name: Nominal efficiency (water)
Properties.Definition: Defines the total efficiency of the water heat production equipment as defined by the manufacturer.

Properties.Name: Nominal electric power
Properties.Definition: Indicates the manufacturer's expected energy consumption.

Properties.Name: Nominal flow
Properties.Definition: Specifies the airflow as designed.

Properties.Name: Nominal heat output (steam)
Properties.Definition: Defines the total nominal heat output as listed by the steam boiler manufacturer.

Properties.Name: Nominal heat output (water)
Properties.Definition: Defines the total nominal heat output as listed by the water boiler manufacturer.

Properties.Name: Nominal power
Properties.Definition: Indicates the nominal power of the cooling unit.

Properties.Name: Nominal supply voltage
Properties.Definition: Gives the nominal voltage of the supply.

Properties.Name: Nominal volume
Properties.Definition: Indicates the nominal volume of the tank.

Properties.Name: Number of buttons
Properties.Definition: Gives the number of gangs/buttons on this switch.

Properties.Name: Number of connections
Properties.Definition: Indicates the number of hose connections on the hydrant (excluding the pumper connection).

Properties.Name: Number of ducts
Properties.Definition: Indicates the number of the chimney drafts, continuous holes in the chimney through which the air passes.

Properties.Name: Numerical identifier
Properties.Definition: Identification code that can be read by the human eye (preferably unique to the type of element in the project), such as a door number.

Properties.Name: Object name
Properties.Definition: Name of the element/sub-element (preferably unique in the project).

Properties.Name: Occupancy number
Properties.Definition: Indicates the number of people required for the activity assigned to this space.

Properties.Name: Occupancy type
Properties.Definition: Defines the intended use of the space.

Properties.Name: Opening type
Properties.Definition: Indication of the requirement of types of window panel operations. Note : although there is an "IfcWindowPanelProperties" property, some softwares do not export sub-component properties. This property has therefore been transferred to the global element.

Properties.Name: Operation type
Properties.Definition: Define the way the door opens. In IFC 2x3,  this property is defined at the panel level (IfcDoorPanel) and not at the door level. In some viewer, you need to select the subcomponant of the door, the doorpanel to see this property.

Properties.Name: Operational efficiency
Properties.Definition: Defines the operational efficiency of the boiler : heat output divided by the total energy input (electrical and fuel).

Properties.Name: Outlet diameter
Properties.Definition: Indicates the outlet diameter of the breeching inlet.

Properties.Name: Passage width
Properties.Definition: Indicates the net passage width.

Properties.Name: Performance
Properties.Definition: Indicates the ratio of output capacity to intake capacity.

Properties.Name: Phasing
Properties.Definition: Determines the phase during which the element is implemented (if the project is carried out in several phases).

Properties.Name: Place of assembly
Properties.Definition: Indicates where the assembly of the element should take place, either in the factory or on site.

Properties.Name: Placement
Properties.Definition: Defines the type of placing.

Properties.Name: Power source
Properties.Definition: Defines the energy source used by the equipment.

Properties.Name: Radiator type
Properties.Definition: Indicates the type of radiator.

Properties.Name: Recessed
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the device is recessed (RECESSED) or put on surface (SURFACE).

Properties.Name: Reinforcement ratio
Properties.Definition: Indicates the ratio of the reinforcement mass (kg) to the (m³) of the concrete element.

Properties.Name: Renovation status (Archicad)
Properties.Definition: Indicates the status of the element, predominantly used in renovation or retrofitting projects. The status can be assigned as "New" - element designed as new addition, "Existing" - element exists and remains, "Demolish" - element existed but is to be demolished, "Temporary" - element will exist only temporarily (like a temporary support structure).

Properties.Name: Required illumination
Properties.Definition: Defines the required average illuminance value for this space (lux, lx = Lumens/m²).

Properties.Name: Required natural ventilation
Properties.Definition: Indicates the requirement of a particular natural air ventilation rate, given in air changes per hour.

Properties.Name: Security rating
Properties.Definition: Indicates the resistance of the door to static and dynamic forces and human human attack.

Properties.Name: Sensible cooling capacity
Properties.Definition: Gives the sensible capacity is the ability of the air conditioner to reduce temperature, while the latent capacity is its ability to remove moisture.

Properties.Name: Skirtingboard finishing
Properties.Definition: Indicates the material of the skirting boards if not modelled separately.

Properties.Name: Solar transmission of glazing
Properties.Definition: Indicates the incident solar radiation that is transmitted directly through the glazing.

Properties.Name: Space name
Properties.Definition: Space name holds the full name of the space, it is often used in addition to the number.

Properties.Name: Space number
Properties.Definition: Space number holds the unique space number from the plan

Properties.Name: Status
Properties.Definition: Indicates the status of the spaces and zones, predominantly used in renovation or retrofitting projects. The status can be assigned as "New" - element designed as new addition, "Existing" - element exists and remains, "Demolish" - element existed but is to be demolished, "Temporary" - element will exist only temporarily (like a temporary support structure).

Properties.Name: Switch function
Properties.Definition: Indicates the type of switching of the switch.

Properties.Name: Thermal conductivity
Properties.Definition: Determines the thermal conductivity (λ-value) of a material, expressed in W/(mK).

Properties.Name: Thermal transmittance
Properties.Definition: Defines the overall heat transfer coefficient through the wall in the direction of heat flow (all materials included) (U-value).

Properties.Name: Total effectiveness
Properties.Definition: Or coefficient of performance. It describes the ratio between the energy used and the heat produced

Properties.Name: Transformer power
Properties.Definition: Indicates the power of the transformer.

Properties.Name: Type activation
Properties.Definition: Defines the type of sprinkler activation.

Properties.Name: Type connection
Properties.Definition: Indicates whether the device is connected using a free plug (TRUE), whether it is directly connected (FALSE) or whether the connection is unknown (UNKOWN).

Properties.Name: Type hydrant
Properties.Definition: Defines the type of hydrant.

Properties.Name: Type of blackout device
Properties.Definition: Specifies the type of sun protection the door or window has.

Properties.Name: Type of coupler
Properties.Definition: Defines the type of breeching inlet.

Properties.Name: Type of coupling
Properties.Definition: Defines the type coupling on the inlet of the breeching inlet.

Properties.Name: Type of hose reel
Properties.Definition: Identifies hosereel type.

Properties.Name: Type of mounting
Properties.Definition: Defines how the luminaire is placed (surface mounted, recessed, etc.)

Properties.Name: Type of placement
Properties.Definition: Indicates how the radiator is designed to be positioned.

Properties.Name: Type of security lighting
Properties.Definition: Indicates the type of security lighting.

Properties.Name: Type of sprinkler
Properties.Definition: Defines the type of sprinkler.

Properties.Name: Type of storage
Properties.Definition: Defines the type of storage.

Properties.Name: Ventilation gap surface
Properties.Definition: Indicates the opening area for air passage (ventilation).

Properties.Name: Voltage
Properties.Definition: Defines the voltage that a device is designed to handle.

Properties.Name: Wall covering thickness
Properties.Definition: Indicates the thickness of the wall finish material if it is not modelled separately.

Properties.Name: Wall finishing
Properties.Definition: Indicates the wall finish material if not modelled separately.

Properties.Name: Work package
Properties.Definition: Determines the batch in which this element is executed.

Properties.Name: Communication protocol
Properties.Definition: The communication protocol defines the communication methods used by the device to deliver the information.

Properties.Name: Construction details
Properties.Definition: The execution details are detailed technical drawings enabling the correct installation of the element.

Properties.Name: Construction principle
Properties.Definition: The construction principle is a note containing a text and/or summary diagrams defining the planned construction system. Example : type of structure, finishing and doors/windows, etc.

Properties.Name: Energy report
Properties.Definition: The energy report includes an energy calculation of heat loss from the project and its technical equipment. Example : energy passport, EPB declaration, etc.

Properties.Name: Environmental performance declaration
Properties.Definition: The environmental performance declaration is a document where the manufacturer declares the environmental impact of the product as defined by EN 15804.

Properties.Name: Expansion joints plan
Properties.Definition: The expansion joint plan shows the location of the joints to allow proper expansion of an element.

Properties.Name: Formwork plan
Properties.Definition: The formwork plan is a construction plan for a reinforced or prestressed concrete structure on which are shown all the dimensions defining the geometry of the structure.

Properties.Name: Geotechnical study report
Properties.Definition: The geotechnical study report is a summary of the geotechnical tests carried out on site and the recommendations to be taken into account.

Properties.Name: Installation instructions
Properties.Definition: The installation instructions contain the instructions for installing the technical component.

Properties.Name: Layout plan
Properties.Definition: The layout plan indicates the assembly of the elements to create a coherent, aesthetically pleasing whole. Example : layout of tiling or metal cassettes on the facade.

Properties.Name: List of doors
Properties.Definition: The door nomenclature is a table listing the doors and their features and equipment.

Properties.Name: List of rooms
Properties.Definition: The list of rooms is a table listing the rooms and their characteristics. It is organised by zone.

Properties.Name: Maintenance instructions
Properties.Definition: The maintenance instructions describes the instructions for servicing the technical equipment.

Properties.Name: Maintenance log
Properties.Definition: The maintenance log is a document that lists the maintenance work carried out on the component: date, person involved, purpose.

Properties.Name: Measurement protocol
Properties.Definition: The measurement protocol defines the calculation rules needed to use and calibrate the equipment.

Properties.Name: Operating loads
Properties.Definition: The operating loads is a document which indicates the loads per part to which the element will be subjected.

Properties.Name: Performances requirements
Properties.Definition: The performance to be achieved covers all the performance requirements that the element must meet. Example : thermal, fire, safety, etc.

Properties.Name: Plan of openings
Properties.Definition: The plan of the openings shows the location of the openings to be created for the passage of ducts and other technical equipment.

Properties.Name: Pre-calculation
Properties.Definition: The pre-calculation includes a note and possibly diagrams indicating, after simplified calculation, the dimensioning required for the element.

Properties.Name: Precise calculation
Properties.Definition: The precise calculation includes a note and possibly diagrams indicating, after detailed calculation, the exact dimensioning required for the element. It concerns techniques.

Properties.Name: Representative image
Properties.Definition: The representative image shows the element as envisaged. It shows the aesthetics, position and overall dimensions of the component. It can be found directly in the data sheet once the product has been chosen.

Properties.Name: Shading principle
Properties.Definition: The shading principle is a note containing a text and/or diagram describing the system envisaged for obscuring the glazing.

Properties.Name: Single-line diagram
Properties.Definition: The single-line diagram is presented in the form of a plan and shows the circuits of an electrical, sanitary or ventilation installation. It shows the connections and networks.

Properties.Name: Space planning diagram
Properties.Definition: The space planning diagram is an organisation chart showing the spaces grouped by zone and the links between them.

Properties.Name: Space requirement schema
Properties.Definition: The space requirement schema represents the space required to install the element and the space needed for its operation and maintenance. For example : the overall dimensions of escalator equipment, the dimensions of technical voids for the passage of ducts and pipes, the space required for suspended ceiling techniques, the space required to replace a part in a boiler.

Properties.Name: Specific elements plan
Properties.Definition: The plan of the specific elements is a complementary document to the other required documents and is essential for a good understanding of the implementation of the element.

Properties.Name: Specifications
Properties.Definition: The specifications set out all the requirements that the component must meet.

Properties.Name: Stability report
Properties.Definition: The stability report includes the calculation note for the project's structural elements and the load description.

Properties.Name: Steel reinforcement plan
Properties.Definition: The reinforcement plan shows the reinforcement to be used and its specific characteristics.

Properties.Name: Technical recommendations
Properties.Definition: The technical recommendations set out the technical requirements that the component must meet.

Properties.Name: Technical sheets
Properties.Definition: The technical sheet for a manufactured item lists its performance and technical characteristics. A representative image is attached to this document.

Properties.Name: Zone data sheet
Properties.Definition: The zone sheet is a description of the zone, listing the common characteristics of the areas that make up the zone.
